segment.source: title: Step 1: Make sure your machine is compatible
segment.target: title: Step 1: Make sure your machine is compatible

segment.source: Operating System Compatibility
segment.target: Operating System Compatibility

segment.source: 30-Nov update.
segment.target: 30-Nov update.

segment.source: The Hyper-V role can only be installed on the Pro, Enterprise and Education editions of Windows 10.
segment.target: The Hyper-V role can only be installed on the Pro, Enterprise and Education editions of Windows 10.

segment.source: If you are using the Home, Mobile or Mobile Enterprise edition of Windows 10, the Hyper-V role cannot be used.
segment.target: If you are using the Home, Mobile or Mobile Enterprise edition of Windows 10, the Hyper-V role cannot be used.

segment.source: Windows 10 Home edition can be upgraded to Windows 10 Professional.
segment.target: Windows 10 Home edition can be upgraded to Windows 10 Professional.

segment.source: To do so open up settings > Update and Security > Activation.
segment.target: To do so open up settings > Update and Security > Activation.

segment.source: Here you can visit the store and purchase an upgrade.
segment.target: Here you can visit the store and purchase an upgrade.

segment.source: Hardware Compatibility
segment.target: Hardware Compatibility

segment.source: While this document will not provide a complete list of Hyper-V compatible hardware the following items are necessary:
segment.target: While this document will not provide a complete list of Hyper-V compatible hardware the following items are necessary:

segment.source: 64-bit Processor with Second Level Address Translation (SLAT).
segment.target: 64-bit Processor with Second Level Address Translation (SLAT).

segment.source: VM Monitor Mode Extension must be present.
segment.target: VM Monitor Mode Extension must be present.

segment.source: Minimum of 4 GB memory, however because virtual machines will share this memory with the Hyper-V host, you will want to provide enough memory to handle the expected virtual workload.
segment.target: Minimum of 4 GB memory, however because virtual machines will share this memory with the Hyper-V host, you will want to provide enough memory to handle the expected virtual workload.

segment.source: The following items will need to be enabled in the system bios:
segment.target: The following items will need to be enabled in the system bios:

segment.source: Virtualization
segment.target: Virtualization

segment.source: Data Execution Prevention
segment.target: Data Execution Prevention

segment.source: Verify Hardware Compatibility
segment.target: Verify Hardware Compatibility

segment.source: To verify compatibly, open up PowerShell or a command prompt (cmd.exe) and type .
segment.target: To verify compatibly, open up PowerShell or a command prompt (cmd.exe) and type .

segment.source: This will return information about Hyper-V compatibility.
segment.target: This will return information about Hyper-V compatibility.

segment.source: If all listed item have a value of ‘Yes’ your system can run the Hyper-V role.
segment.target: If all listed item have a value of ‘Yes’ your system can run the Hyper-V role.

segment.source: If any item returns ‘No’, check the requirements listed in this document and make adjustments where possible.
segment.target: If any item returns ‘No’, check the requirements listed in this document and make adjustments where possible.

segment.source: Existing Hyper-V Host
segment.target: Existing Hyper-V Host

segment.source: If you run systeminfo.exe on an existing Hyper-V host, the Hyper-V Requirements section will read:
segment.target: If you run systeminfo.exe on an existing Hyper-V host, the Hyper-V Requirements section will read:

segment.target: Next Step:

segment.source: Step 2: Install Hyper-V
segment.target: Step 2: Install Hyper-V
